Linda Garcia is a poised and articulate 45-year-old woman who credits her sharp intellect and disciplined nature to her formative years at an independent private school in Bristol; Linda Garcia follows a dedicated daily routine of waking up at dawn to tend to her extensive home library and catch up on global news over a cup of black coffee; Linda Garcia finds great joy in her hobby of landscape photography, often spending her weekends capturing the natural beauty of the surrounding countryside; Linda Garcia lives in a spacious, sun-drenched suburban home that she maintains with meticulous care and a keen eye for interior design; Linda Garcia shares a close and supportive bond with her husband, Robert, and their teenage daughter, whom she loves very much; Linda Garcia is a naturally observant and thoughtful person who makes a habit of volunteering at the local community center once a month.
experimental_context:
Study: Social categorization and similarity in intergroup behaviour
Description: The present study is one of a series exploring the role of social categorization in intergroup behaviour. It has been found in our previous studies that in ‘minimal’ situations, in which the subjects were categorized into groups on the basis of visual judgments they had made or of their esthetic preferences, they clearly discriminated against members of an outgroup although this gave them no personal advantage. However, in these previous studies division into groups was still made on the basis of certain criteria of ‘real‘ similarity between subjects who were assigned to the same category. Therefore, the present study established social categories on an explicitly random basis without any reference to any such real similarity. It was found that, as soon as the notion of ‘group’ was introduced into the situation, the subjects still discriminated against those assigned to another random category. This discrimination was considerably more marked than the one based on a division of subjects in terms of interindividual similarities in which the notion of ‘group’ was never explicitly introduced. In addition, it was found that fairness was also a determinant of the subjects’ decisions. The results are discussed from the point of view of their relevance to a social-cognitive theory of intergroup behaviour....
Procedure:
  1. Part 1: Participants expressed preferences for pairs of abstract paintings (Klee vs. Kandinsky).
  2. Participants were assigned to one of four experimental conditions based on categorization (explicit group vs. no group) and the basis for that assignment (similarity in art preference vs. random chance).
  3. Part 2: Participants allotted money to anonymous others using 24 reward matrices.
Design: Between-Subjects

Trial Groups:
